Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for ACM HPDC 2015

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: 24th ACM International Symposium on High Performance Distributed Computing (HPDC) seeks to increase student participation in symposium and the field. The proposed funding would support the travel of eligible US students to the symposium. Recipients would be able to attend the main conference, workshops, and tutorials. Travel grants encourage the research interests and the involvement of students in the field who are not well funded and those who are just beginning their participation in the field or are interested in entering it. A special effort is made to reach out to women and under-represented minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Symposium on High-Performance Parallel and Distributed Computing (HPDC) is the premier forum for presenting the latest research findings on the design and use of parallel and distributed systems for high-end computing, collaboration, data analysis, and other innovative applications. This project has provided travel grants to support eligible U.S. students to attend this symposium and fostered the research interests and the involvement of students in the parallel and distributed computing field. Specifically, the project has achieved the following accomplishments.

First, it has increased student participation in the symposium. A total of 22 students from 16 different U.S. institutions were awarded the travel grants, who all responded via the exit survey that the travel grants were essential for them to cover the travel expenses and attend the symposium. About half of these students responded that it was their first time attending a conference and for some of them it was also their first time giving a conference presentation. Many students spoke highly about the quality of the symposium and expressed interests in attending future HPDC symposiums.

Second, it has increased student participation in the HPDC field. The awardees who had paper/poster presentations at the symposium and/or its associated workshops all responded that they received valuable feedback to their work. All awardees responded highly positively regarding what they learned from the symposium/workshop presentations. All of them confirmed that they had helpful interactions with symposium/workshop attendees for improving their research and building their professional networks. Many students also indicated that these interactions at the symposium led to future collaboration and employment opportunities.

Third, the travel grants have promoted the participation of students from underrepresented groups in the HPDC field. Among the 22 awardees, five are woman and one is Hispanic.

Overall, through the project, students were provided substantial training and professional development opportunities, including but not limited to, learning about leading-edge research from the symposium/workshop presentations, learning presentation skills from giving conference talks and attending other presentations, learning how to improve and/or expand their research from audience feedback, establishing collaborative relationships by interacting with other symposium attendees, and creating employment opportunities based on these interactions.
